issues.description: Resource naming mismatch between the problem statement and the solution implementation: the problem statement repeatedly specifies the REST endpoints under the /persons path (e.g. POST /persons, GET /persons, PUT /persons/{personId}, DELETE /persons/{personId}), but the solution's server implementation exposes the person endpoints under /people (PersonResource uses @GetMapping("people"), @PostMapping("people"), @PutMapping("people/{personId}"), @DeleteMapping("people/{personId}")). This cross-artifact inconsistency will confuse students about the correct endpoint names to use and prevents a straightforward mapping from the exercise description to the provided reference server implementation.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the resource path names consistent. Either (A) update the solution server to expose the person endpoints under /persons (change @GetMapping/@PostMapping/@PutMapping/@DeleteMapping to "persons" and "persons/{personId}"), and ensure the client uses /persons for all requests; or (B) update the problem statement and any instructions that reference /persons to use /people. Preferably align everything to /persons to match the wording in the problem description.

issues.description: Inner-solution inconsistency in the client implementation: the solution's PersonController uses mixed paths when talking to the server — addPerson() and updatePerson() call POST/PUT on "people" and "people/{id}", while deletePerson() and getAllPersons() call DELETE/GET on "persons" and "persons" respectively. This inconsistent use of "people" vs "persons" within the solution client will confuse students and is a structural defect in the reference implementation.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the client call the same endpoints as the server. Update the PersonController to consistently use the same resource path for all operations (either always "persons" or always "people") matching the server's endpoints. If you keep the server endpoints as /people (not recommended given the problem text), change deletePerson() and getAllPersons() to use "people"; otherwise change addPerson() and updatePerson() to use "persons".

issues.description: Endpoint path naming for the Person resource differs between the problem statement and the server implementation. The problem statement explicitly documents the persons endpoints as /persons (POST /persons, GET /persons, PUT /persons/{personId}, DELETE /persons/{personId}) but the solution server implements these endpoints under the path /people (e.g., @GetMapping("people"), @PostMapping("people"), etc.). This mismatch makes it unclear to students which path they should implement or call and will likely lead to failed requests or wasted time trying to reconcile the two names.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the Person endpoint path consistent across problem statement, template and solution. Preferably align source code to the problem statement by renaming the server mappings from /people to /persons (change @GetMapping("people") -> @GetMapping("persons"), @PostMapping("people") -> @PostMapping("persons"), @PutMapping("people/{personId}") -> @PutMapping("persons/{personId}"), @DeleteMapping(...) similarly). Alternatively, if /people is the desired canonical path, update the problem statement to document /people instead of /persons. Ensure the client controller URIs are updated to match the chosen path.

issues.description: In the solution client implementation, the PersonController uses both "people" and "persons" paths when making requests. Specifically, addPerson and updatePerson use the path "people" while deletePerson and getAllPersons use the path "persons". This internal inconsistency in the client will cause some operations to target different endpoints than others and will confuse students trying to trace request flow between client and server.
issues.suggested_fix: Choose a single path name and use it consistently in the client. Update PersonController to use the same endpoint path for all operations (POST, PUT, GET, DELETE). For example, if the server is using /persons, change the client calls to .uri("persons") and .uri("persons/" + id) for all methods; if the server uses /people, make all client calls use /people. Also ensure the server and problem statement are aligned with the same chosen name.
